text:
If you use freelancer help for content updates, what's your process?

I've always handled updates myself but I'm swamped with work right now and will like to outsource it (70+ pages :woman-facepalming:). I already work with a few freelancers to create content following my process. I've also always given them almost everything including directions, keywords etc 

Right now, I want to be able to simply hand them a URL, have them copy and update the content in a Google doc, then send to the editor for edits and publishing. 

How do you hands-off when you outsource updates? How do you ensure a good ROI whe  you're handsoff?

elements.text:
If you use freelancer help for content updates, what's your process?

I've always handled updates myself but I'm swamped with work right now and will like to outsource it (70+ pages

text:
Hmm…I'm not sure there is a way to be super hands off when handling content. If your goal is to hand it off and keep your work to a minimum I would start by only working with freelancers you trust and that have done great work with you in the past or people who know how to update content.

I find that most updates require the same things. Looking for new stats, adding new content to align with competitors, making sure SEO best practices are followed, etc. Maybe make a content update checklist that each person can follow to make the process simple? That way they hopefully know when they have updated the content in align with your needs?

elements.text: Hmm…I'm not sure there is a way to be super hands off when handling content. I find that most updates require the same things. Looking for new stats, adding new content to align with competitors, making sure SEO best practices are followed, etc. Maybe make a content update checklist that each person can follow to make the process simple? That way they hopefully know when they have updated the content in align with your needs?

text: I think a content update checklist is a great idea. I do updates for a few clients and that’s essentially what they give their writers (along with additional notes if needed on a specific piece).

elements.text: I think a content update checklist is a great idea. I do updates for a few clients and that’s essentially what they give their writers (along with additional notes if needed on a specific piece).

text: Along with an update checklist as mentioned above, a brand style guide, goals for the specific piece of content, and any relevant keyword research would be helpful!

elements.text: Along with an update checklist as mentioned above, a brand style guide, goals for the specific piece of content, and any relevant keyword research would be helpful!

text: Freelancer here! Here’s my perspective: I can handle a lot of work hands-off as long as I know what KIND of updates a client is looking for. General improvements to writing quality? Structural updates for skimmability (headers, bullet points, etc?) Adding internal links (and if so, what are your highest-priority pages?) New stats? New customer quotes from existing case studies? More CTAs? Target keywords added/updated? So basically, agree with everyone else here that a simple checklist would go a long way, along with an example of an existing page that you love so I can understand what you’re looking for.

text: I really like this one that I think someone else in this community shared a while back <https://manual.withcompound.com/>

elements.text: I really like this one that I think someone else in this community shared a while back

text: Freelancer here too :hand: I think if you're clear yourself on 'what success looks like' and you can explain that in a practical way to your team, a good writer should be able to take that and run with it.

elements.text: I think if you're clear yourself on 'what success looks like' and you can explain that in a practical way to your team, a good writer should be able to take that and run with it.

text:
Hi, all! Long-time lurker :spider:, first-time poster :grin:!

This is kind of a weird question that’s about internal rather than external content strategy.

I’m currently revamping my company’s INTERNAL Marketing team newsletter to be sent company-wide monthly. I’ve worked on my fair share of internal newsletters, some of which were somewhat informative and some of which were downright a waste of Marketing’s time.

What sort of content (what Marketing’s been working on, company cultural stuff, etc.) would you think is most valuable to include in an internal newsletter that would get the rest of your company excited and always looking forward to the next one?

elements.text:
!

What sort of content (what Marketing’s been working on, company cultural stuff, etc.) would you think is most valuable to include in an internal newsletter that would get the rest of your company excited and always looking forward to the next one?

text:
You could ask them??

I generally find external teams are often interested in seeing what is creative shipping (new ads, big rock content, campaign collateral, case studies). I've sometimes presented it as a quiz (e.g. which ad do you think got more clicks?) so there's a interactive component.

Apart from that, they'll often want to know / learn about key results; CAC, CAC:LTV, ARPU, etc. You could take one metric a month, explain it, show where you're at as a company and what the industry benchmark is.

GTM plans for upcoming product releases are often interesting too.

As with any content, it depends where your audience is at, I imagine you want to cater to a wide range of appetite/understanding of marketing... so test, test, test!

text:
Speak to them like you would in a slack message versus an email: can you use gifs (not all email services support these!), slang, inside jokes, or silly examples? 

What are you most proud of? What projects rallied cross-functional teams? Who can you highlight as a marketing champion outside of the marketing org? 

I love Jane's comments about explaining parts of the marketing world. What do people misunderstand or make assumptions about the most? 

And ... let us know what you decide!

text:
What kind of content strategy should I use being Google ads specialist??

I am Google ads specialist. 

Can anyone guide me how should I post content to establish myself as authority in my Google ads niche so that people can trust my expertise. 

In case I start writing blog post regarding Google ads, what if  people learn from my blogs and start running Google ads themself?  

I mean should I put  in- depth content or only superficial level content. 

Or is there any other  content strategy you can suggest ? 

Please help me
